qas.question: How many transmitters does currently CBC operate after 2012?
When did the CBC announce service would be discontinued to analogue transmitters?
How much did CBC say they would save by ceasing analogue operation?
The CBC's yearly operating costs were recorded as this amount?
The CRTC has limited the CBC to operating how many digital transmitters?
Unable to meet the conversion deadline, the CRTC took possession of how many of the CBC's analogue transmitters?
The CRTC encouraged the use of there to maintain over-the-air signals?
The CBC decided to terminate all digital and analog broadcasts on this date?

context: CBC announced on April 4, 2012, that it will shut down all of its approximately <b5_0>620<b5_0/> analogue television transmitters on <a1_0><b7_0>July 31, 2012<b7_0/><a1_0/> with no plans to install digital transmitters in their place, thus reducing the total number of the corporation's television transmitters across the country down to <a0_0><b4_0>27<b4_0/><a0_0/>. According to the CBC, this would reduce the corporation's yearly costs by <a2_0><b3_0>$10 million<b3_0/><a2_0/>. No plans have been announced to use <b6_0>subchannels<b6_0/> to maintain over-the-air signals for both CBC and Radio-Canada in markets where the corporation has one digital transmitter. In fact, in its CRTC application to shut down all of its analogue television transmitters, the CBC communicated its opposition to use of subchannels, citing costs, amongst other reasons.
